Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant has a fairly arguable case to justify judicial review of the PRRA officer's decision denying humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Governing_Law: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide supporting evidence for claimed personalized risk
Evidence_Type: Lack of supporting evidence for compulsory military service risk in Albania
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence based on risk of compulsory military service in Albania
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate a fairly arguable case for judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to support the claim
Application_Factor: Personalized risk due to compulsory military service
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no serious question raised
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness not specified; assessed under fairly arguable threshold for leave

Application_Facts: Applicant claims she will face persecution from former traffickers if returned to Romania due to inadequate state protection.
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer erred by relying on Romania's efforts rather than its effectiveness.
Evidence_Used: Evidence shows corruption, recapture risks, and insufficient police capability.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer relied on insufficient evidence of effective state protection.
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed until judicial review application is resolved.
Outcome: Stay of removal granted pending judicial review.
Remedy_Sought: Protection from deportation due to risk of harm
Legal_Standard_Applied: State protection requires both the will and capacity of the government to effectively implement legislation and programs to protect victims.
Standard_of_Review: Tripartite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Applicant has raised a serious issue, faces irreparable harm, and the balance of convenience favors granting a stay of removal.

Criminality_Severity: High – risk of retribution and sexual exploitation
Risk_Nature: Targeted harm by non-state actors due to prior exploitation
Evidence_Credibility: Credible based on consistency and corroboration
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Inadequate state protection for trafficking victims
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97(1) IRPA – Danger to life, liberty, or cruel treatment
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution due to ineffective state protection
Legal_Framework: International human rights law, domestic refugee protection framework
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed pending judicial review
Targeted_Group: Trafficking survivors returning to home country
State_Protection_Assessment: Romanian state lacks capacity due to corruption and weak enforcement
Legal_Provision: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate – lack of will and capacity
Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with state complicity or neglect
Perpetrator_Entity: Human traffickers, potentially aided by corrupt officials

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess state protection
Application_Facts: PRRA Officer ignored evidence of corruption and specific threats; focused on formal measures over actual protection
Procedural_Issue: Error in applying legal standard for state protection
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to review PRRA decisions
Evidence_Used: Evidence of police corruption, inadequate response, and personal threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer failed to consider key evidence on effectiveness of protection
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims treated as credible by the court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Tripartite test for stay: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Applicant demonstrated serious issue regarding state protection, risk of irreparable harm, and favorable balance of convenience

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections related to stay and removal
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's H&C application failed to consider personalized risks; removal would lead to potential imprisonment and economic hardship
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess individualized risks in H&C application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of integration in Canada, risk of imprisonment upon return
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not properly assess personal risk factors
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Integration into Canadian society and risk of irreparable harm justify stay

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, claimed risks upon return and strong ties to Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: H&C application denied without adequate assessment of personal circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, integration, family ties, risk of imprisonment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Personalized risks not assessed by decision maker
Crimes.Outcome: Allowed to remain until H&C decision is judicially reviewed
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Irreparable harm likely and balance of convenience favors applicant due to integration
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Misrepresentation in immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Accuracy and honesty in immigration status declaration
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 40
Crimes.Outcome: Stay of removal granted pending review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about credibility due to prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentation of military evasion, economic circumstances, community integration
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds despite inadmissibility
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Integration in Canada and risk of imprisonment
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider individualized risks in H&C assessment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Totality of circumstances for H&C consideration
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Personalized risk factors such as military evasion consequences
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of residence, family ties, employment
Crimes.Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 397 of the Federal Court Rules
Application_Facts: The Minister sought reconsideration of a July 20, 2004 order permitting Tatiana Lazareva's application for permanent residence to be assessed in Canada; the Court had previously ruled against removal to Russia.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for reconsideration under Rule 397 based on new arguments by the Minister
Jurisdictional_Issue: Court's authority to direct Minister's actions under IRPA and prevent frustration of its orders
Evidence_Used: Arguments regarding Russia's acceptance of Lazareva, legality of prohibiting removal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No inadvertent error found; new arguments not grounds for reconsideration
Outcome: Original Court order stands; Minister must process Lazareva's application in Canada
Relief_Sought: Reconsideration of prior order by the Minister
Remedy_Sought: Court to alter or set aside its previous decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 397 allows reconsideration only for inadvertent errors, not for appeals or new legal arguments
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, as it involves questions of jurisdiction and interpretation of court rules
Decision_Rationale: The Court found no error in its prior decision; the Minister's arguments did not meet the threshold for reconsideration under Rule 397; the Court has jurisdiction to ensure its orders are not frustrated
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court, Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Legal_Issue: Can a removal deferral be granted based solely on an undecided humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application?
Legal_Provision: Removal orders must be executed as soon as reasonably practicable unless special considerations exist
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Outstanding H&C application alone does not constitute special considerations
Evidence_Ignored: H&C application status without additional special considerations
Legal_Standard: No reviewable error if decision is reasonable

Violation_Type: Failure to comply with residency conditions
Remaining in Canada after legal status expired
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - timely removal requirement
Application_Facts: Refugee claims and PRRA applications were denied
Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral based on ongoing H&C process
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing special considerations beyond H&C application
Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal pending H&C decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Removal must proceed unless statutory stay or discretion applies
Decision_Rationale: An undecided H&C application alone does not justify deferral

Legal_Issue: Is the PRRA Officer's decision regarding state protection in Honduras reasonable?
Governing_Law: Rule: State protection analysis requires assessing the operational effectiveness of a country’s protective measures, especially in countries with acknowledged institutional failings.
Evidence_Assessment: The PRRA Officer dismissed his claims due to lack of police reports, ignoring evidence of police ineffectiveness and corruption.
Decision_Outcome: The judicial review is granted, the decision is quashed and referred back for reconsideration by a different officer.
Legal_Rule: State protection analysis requires assessing the operational effectiveness of a country’s protective measures, especially in countries with acknowledged institutional failings.
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of returning to Honduras due to gang violence and inadequate state protection.
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision overturned, case remanded for new assessment.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence of police ineffectiveness and corruption in Honduras.
Legal_Framework: PRRA process, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to Pre-Removal Risk Assessment

Legal_Issue: Is the PRRA Officer's decision regarding state protection in Honduras reasonable?
Governing_Law: Rule: Findings of state protection must be reasonable and consider the operational effectiveness of state measures, especially in countries with acknowledged failings.
Outcome: Decision overturned, case remanded for reassessment by another officer.
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to Pre-Removal Risk Assessment
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of return due to inadequate state protection in Honduras
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Operational effectiveness of Honduran state protection
Application_Error: Failed to assess functionality of state protection, focused only on institutional existence
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of corruption and gang violence undermining state protection
Application_Factor: Nature and severity of gang-related risks
Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, referred back for new decision

Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions regarding attendance at refugee proceedings
Governing_Law: Rule: Decisions on state protection must reasonably assess the operational effectiveness of state measures, considering country conditions.
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to appear for refugee hearing, later returned to Canada claiming fear of gang violence.
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to appear and illegal re-entry
Procedural_Issue: Failure to appear leading to dismissal and deportation

Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not assess effectiveness of state protection despite available evidence
Decision_Outcome: Decision overturned due to unreasonable assessment
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of PRRA based on fear of gang violence and police retaliation
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different PRRA officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer unreasonably dismissed fear of police retaliation without proper analysis

Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer's decision on state protection in Honduras was reasonable.
Governing_Law: Rule: State protection analysis must assess operational effectiveness of state measures, especially in countries with systemic failures.
Evidence_Assessment: Officer dismissed applicant’s fear of police retaliation without sufficient evidence or analysis.
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision quashed and referred back for reevaluation.
Legal_Rule: State protection analysis must assess operational effectiveness of state measures, especially in countries with systemic failures.
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by MS-13 gang and inadequate state protection in Honduras

Key_Evidence_Considered: Risk from MS-13, history of illegal return, lack of state protection in Honduras
Remedy_Requested: Reevaluation of PRRA decision by a different officer
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections on Pre-Removal Risk Assessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's assessment of H&C grounds under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer focused on misrepresentation but failed to assess broader credibility in context of H&C factors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application records, family status documents, declarations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to declare dependents leading to inadmissibility

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential for family reunification in Canada, best interests of children in Canadian context
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties in Canada, best interests of the child
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by another officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependants in application for permanent residence

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Exclusion from family class due to non-disclosure of dependents
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Children’s current living conditions, potential for family unity in Canada

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Emphasis on compliance with immigration rules and prior misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Family documentation, affidavits, country condition reports
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Redetermination of H&C application by a different officer

Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of time in Canada, impact on children, stability of family unit

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether conditions under IRPA are justified and proportional to national security danger

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Security certificate issued due to alleged misrepresentations in refugee claim
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing risk due to lack of cooperation and potential re-establishment of dangerous contacts
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Proportionality between liberty and national security
Crimes.Application_Factor: Diminished danger over time but latent threat remains

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Obstruction of justice through non-cooperation and deception
Crimes.Victim_Status: National security institutions and judicial process
Aggravating_Factors: History of lying about terrorist contacts
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Alleged links to terrorist organizations and prior untruthfulness
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential to undermine investigation or re-engage in illicit networks
Crimes.Threat_Source: Mr. Mahjoub’s secretive behavior and lack of transparency
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Institutional integrity of immigration and security processes
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: High – supported by multiple judicial reviews
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistently found untruthful across multiple proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.82(2)(b) and common law principles on obstruction

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to lawfulness and proportionality of release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether continued conditions infringe Charter rights disproportionately
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA and Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court reviewed public and confidential evidence including compliance history
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Most conditions upheld with minor modifications
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show conditions are no longer necessary
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of cooperation and credibility concerns weigh against relaxation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Conditions must minimally impair rights while addressing danger
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.82(5), Charter s.7 and s.9
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued health impacts and rights violations justify lifting conditions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Repeal or significant reduction of release conditions
Crimes.Outcome: Minor adjustments granted; most conditions remain

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Full or partial discharge from restrictive measures
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to believe poses danger
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public safety outweighs individual liberty absent demonstrated trustworthiness

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Perjury undermines trust essential for conditional release

Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show lack of state protection

Evidence_Credibility: Undermined by lack of corroboration or reporting

Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of criminal elements due to past incidents
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of state efforts despite systemic issues

Risk_Assessment: Risks arising from involvement in an armed robbery case

Decision_Rationale: Lack of sufficient evidence to demonstrate exceptional hardship or compelling reasons for exemption

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed threats from FARC in Colombia and lack of safe internal flight alternative (IFA) in Pereira; Board found FARC threat concentrated elsewhere and insufficient evidence that applicant would be targeted in Pereira
Procedural_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining an IFA existed
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence, applicant's testimony, evidence on FARC activities and conditions in Pereira
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof that FARC could locate or target the applicant in Pereira; lack of evidence of adverse conditions in Pereira
Decision_Outcome: Board determined IFA in Pereira was available
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Internal Flight Alternative test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution in IFA location; (2) reasonable conditions for seeking refuge
Decision_Rationale: Threat from FARC was not established in Pereira; conditions in Pereira did not rise to level of unreasonableness; psychological effects alone did not undermine safety
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant must accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application; Mr. Haj-Kamali's absences were miscalculated by up to 136 days
Residency_Compliance: Alleged insufficient physical presence; calculation error and legal test ambiguity identified
Procedural_Issue: Miscalculation of absences, ambiguous application of legal test (physical presence vs. centralized mode of existence)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate calculation of absence days, lack of clarity in interpreting residency
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application due to insufficient residency
Outcome: Remitted to Citizenship Court for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application with correct factual and legal assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act – 1,095-day residency requirement
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness (factual findings), Reasonableness simpliciter (mixed fact and law)
Decision_Rationale: Potential factual error in calculating absences and unclear legal standard may have affected outcome

Legal_Issue: Best interests of children in H&C assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Harm to children, potential separation, father's presence
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds, best interests of children
Key_Evidence_Considered: Impact of separation on children, benefits of parental presence
Legal_Framework: Baker v. Canada, Suresh v. Canada
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer denied application based on risk of separation
Outcome: Case remitted to a different visa officer
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of IRPA

Legal_Issue: Whether the adjudicator correctly interpreted s. 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code regarding jurisdiction over the unjust dismissal complaint
Evidence_Assessment: Adjudicator found Ocean Services failed to prove a bona fide layoff; replacement of two ships with four indicated no lack of work or function discontinuance
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed Ocean Services' application for judicial review
Burden_of_Proof: On employer (Ocean Services) to demonstrate layoff was due to lack of work or discontinuance of function
Credibility_Factor: Adjudicator's factual findings were deemed reasonable by the Federal Court
Legal_Rule: Under s. 242(3.1)(a), adjudicators lack jurisdiction if dismissal resulted from lack of work or discontinuance of function
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal interpretation; reasonableness for factual findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Guenette alleged unjust dismissal; employer claimed jurisdictional bar under s. 242(3.1)(a)
Outcome_on_Merits: Adjudicator had jurisdiction; complaint was validly before them
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of ships operated before and after reorganization; operational changes at Ocean Services
Legal_Framework: Federal administrative law and labour law under the Canada Labour Code
Defendant_Response: Ocean Services argued the adjudicator lacked jurisdiction due to layoff for lack of work
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, operational records, organizational changes
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn adjudicator's jurisdictional finding
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; adjudicator’s decision upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Environmental Assessment and Duty to Consult
Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 16 of the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act (CEAA)
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consultation and accommodation of Aboriginal rights
Potential negative impacts on traditional land use and caribou herds
Decision_Outcome: Crown's duty to consult was substantially satisfied
Consultation process deemed reasonable despite minor deficiencies
Institutional_Action: Federal Court review of environmental assessment and consultation process
State_Protection_Assessment: Duty to consult fulfilled through JRP process
Credibility: Claims found credible enough to warrant review, but not sufficient to overturn decision
Legal_Provision: Section 35 of The Constitution Act, 1982
Section 16 of CEAA
State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate consultation and mitigation measures in place
Victim_Basis: Indigenous group asserting traditional and treaty rights

Application_Facts: Male applicant appointed as a land surveyor in Haiti; received threats due to political connections; claimed persecution based on this role
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal's failure to properly assess individualized risk; decision found unreasonable on judicial review
Evidence_Used: Threats linked to appointment as land surveyor; political ties; personal targeting evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal overlooked specific evidence of personal targeting
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal initially denied protection, finding only generalized risk
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a differently constituted tribunal
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred by treating the risk as generalized despite evidence of personal targeting related to political circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB); Federal Court on review

Legal_Issue: Is the trademark 'The Mild One' registrable under the Trade-marks Act despite being potentially descriptive?
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under Section 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence showed similar trademarks were registered; structure and disclaimer of 'MILD' contribute to distinctiveness
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court overturned the Registrar's decision
Credibility_Factor: Registrar initially rejected application; additional evidence presented on appeal
Legal_Rule: Section 12(1)(b): prohibits clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive marks; Section 35: allows disclaimers; Section 56(1): provides right of appeal
Standard_of_Review: Statutory appeal standard under the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark is distinctive as a whole despite descriptive component
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similar trademarks previously registered, disclaimer of 'MILD', overall distinctiveness
Legal_Framework: Canadian federal trademark law, Trade-marks Act
Defendant_Response: Registrar opposed registration on grounds of descriptiveness
Remedy_Requested: Registration of the trademark 'The Mild One'
Legal_Provision: Section 12(1)(b), Section 35, Section 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether an oral hearing was required to assess credibility regarding sexual orientation

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged police harassment and torture in India
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide verifiable details and corroborating evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: No procedural or legal error identified
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found – panel assessed available evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Court will not intervene unless decision is unreasonable or capricious
Crimes.Application_Factor: Consistency and plausibility of applicant's account
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of false or unsubstantiated documents/information

Crimes.Violation_Type: Criminality and non-compliance with immigration laws
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, sections related to inadmissibility and Temporary Resident Permit (TRP) discretion
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Farhat convicted of theft under $5,000, overstayed visitor status, previously excluded from Canada for one year
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of non-compliance with immigration laws
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Minister's discretionary decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of compelling evidence to justify TRP issuance
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn Minister's decision via judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No compelling reasons presented to overcome inadmissibility despite family reunification arguments
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Request for family reunification in Canada
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Summary conviction offence, non-violent but relevant for immigration inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Potential risk due to criminality and non-compliance history
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Likelihood of future non-compliance or reoffending
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of conviction and immigration breaches
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as credible by the Minister and court
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code of Canada, section related to theft under $5,000

Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for Convention Refugee or person in need of protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to imputed political activities and family association; alleged torture by Indian police
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, claims of torture and persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence linking claim to Convention grounds; lack of proof that state protection was unavailable
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found the applicant's claims not sufficiently substantiated
Decision_Outcome: RPD determined applicant was not a Convention Refugee nor in need of protection
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention Refugee or person in need of protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention Refugee under s. 96 IRPA; Person in need of protection under s. 97 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's conclusion was reasonable based on lack of sufficient evidence connecting the harm to a Convention ground and availability of state protection in India

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) application denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in finding no unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evidence lacked personalization and credibility regarding hardship in Haiti
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Generalized country condition reports without personal nexus
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to risks in Haiti
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence linking country conditions to personal hardship
Crimes.Application_Error: No error found in officer's assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; officer properly assessed available evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship under s. 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Establishment in Canada and family support in Haiti considered
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application denied, judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with temporary resident status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed since 1995 and made a false refugee claim in 2005
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident, failed refugee claimant
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Made false refugee claim after overstaying
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Seeking H&C relief to overcome immigration violations
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, establishment in Canada, family ties in Haiti
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of personalized evidence of hardship upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance and false claim undermined credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application denied, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation risk due to unauthorized stay upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Exemption from normal immigration requirements under s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No exceptional hardship proven despite long stay
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer and Federal Court on review

Evidence_Sufficiency: evidence of establishment in Canada was overlooked
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act subsection 72(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious Criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Individual_Status_or_Claim: permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Risk_Factor: risk upon return to country of origin
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act subsection 72(1)

Prior_Criminality: criminal convictions leading to deportation order
Risk_Assessment: improper application of H&C risk test
Evidence_Sufficiency: strong ties in Canada including family, employment, community involvement
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
subsection 72(1)
